With this Directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The objective of this Directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.

We want the unjust, meager wages paid to immigrants to disappear and, furthermore, we want average salaries to be dispersed, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require considerable courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and significant sums of money involved in the shadow economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migration flows with generosity, but with responsibility.
It would be easy to succumb to the temptation of not attempting to curtail the informal economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave approximately eight million undocumented immigrants in a state of defenselessness, facing working conditions bordering on slavery.

Esteemed Sirs, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic, and even criminal, sanctions in the most serious cases are necessary to have a deterrent effect on businesses.
We will thus reduce the pool of undeclared economic activity and curtail the incentive for migration generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

Therefore, we wish to continue with the global approach and request that the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Barrot, present as soon as possible the new Blue Cards – quotation marks – for the other occupational categories.

I would like to begin by thanking the three speakers for their work. As rapporteur for the shadow report on fishing, I will refer to
To this specific report, beginning by congratulating Mr. Saris Bolski on the outcome of his work and for the collaboration he offered to the other groups to achieve a consensus result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, so too does this Chamber know how to demonstrate cohesion around the evaluation and promotion of major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The focus of our Group, the Social Group, has been directed in a twofold manner: on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce key issues for us, transversally across all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change and the promotion of the

Peace across the entire planet or a wager on human development. On the other hand, suggesting elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of fishing in relation to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or introducing them as new elements if they were absent.
In this way, we have, for example, achieved a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and increased relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and sometimes not even then.
Regarding Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current processes of negotiating association agreements, the first of a directional nature that will conclude the European Union’s history.

Regarding the Mediterranean, we have adopted a reductionist approach that only addresses security in order to instead encompass the rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona Process.

Regarding the amendments to the Po, our Group has not submitted any, believing that they would somehow reinforce the balance achieved through the commitments and, therefore, we will oppose the majority of the amendments in order not to weaken the agreement reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has concluded with a victory for the "yes" vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunity in the campaign, and that the incumbent party has enjoyed the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.

In that regard, we criticize the decision by the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament, and even more so the manner in which that expulsion was carried out. However, we appeal to this Assembly to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local legislation, and even less so that they insult a head of state, however criticizable that head of state may be.
These attitudes are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.

Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an electoral and international accompaniment group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that Group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with an overall positive assessment of the process concerning its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he noted that they sought to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, levied serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and ran afoul of interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not foster any type of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
Conversely, it would be incumbent upon Mr. Put to provide explanations to this Chamber regarding actions that affect us all.

Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a report from the commission, a report on the application of Regulation 1/2006/EC of the
Council Decision of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the judicial authorities of Member States in the obtaining of evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a decidedly non-community sphere, an intergovernmental sphere in which, from the Council, through Regulation, efforts have been made to foster cooperation between those judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been planned, for example, the issuing of practical guides, the utilization of electronic media, etc. But I recognize that action on the part of the Commission is quite difficult.

I am aware of what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to accomplish it given the immense difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation represents.

If we are requesting the judicial authorities who collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities who handle 22 different languages with very distinct legal systems from one another, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has observed that the results are not good, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and, of course, that we do not have the resources to do so.
Ideally, one would have material resources available.
For example, what might be the Commission’s approach to adopting judicial organs, particularly those of a lower level incorporating technological elements such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve it.
I believe the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We should reinforce this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, everything pertaining to the training of judges is fundamental.
This is something the commission itself also cannot do.
However, the Commission can indeed stimulate the development of this type of training courses within communities and regarding the different legal systems.
There is a significant difficulty, which is the language problem—that is, how can one communicate, let us say, a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge with such disparate languages.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to manage their own law, which is already complex in itself, be obligated to have knowledge for this type of [matter].
What practical steps can we take to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?

There is a degree of imprecision in this 2001 regulation, a somewhat voluntary aspect, and I’m not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or if it can be used to achieve progress.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we experienced a major maritime accident, that of the Erika ship near the French coast, which lent its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at addressing and preventing accidents.

We believed we had already banished the danger, but shortly thereafter the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the oil slick, originating from another accident even greater than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, within the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the excessive resistance we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States who rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, as a result of the cuts instigated by the Council, they proved ineffective in their initial drafting.

We test the regulations for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for large oil catastrophes, safe havens, and now we review and approve the liability of passenger shipping companies, the investigation of

maritime accidents, the Community system for the tracking and information on maritime traffic, control by the Port State of the port and, finally, the Regulation and Directive relating to organizations for inspection and recognition of ships.
And all of this is good and desirable to come into effect and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible timeframe.
Therefore, I feel satisfied.
But the legislature ends, I leave Parliament, and I depart with the regret of not having managed to establish as mandatory the introduction of control systems that exist.
They are patented to determine when and how much sludge and fuel tank waste has been illegally discharged into the sea by a specific vessel.
That is to say, a kind of black boxes, void meters that can be inspected by maritime authorities whenever a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment greater attention and stricter procedures to address the significant pollution we produce, and if we fail to do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, causing us to pay a high price.
I trust that it will not be necessary to wait another ten years to more effectively and efficiently control illegal marine party fishing.

Mr. President, the revision of the Rovvilleta Directive is a matter of considerable importance that occupies and concerns us all, particularly peripheral countries that feel they are victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of external costs of road transport, attributing three new costs: atmospheric pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal—who uses pays and who pollutes pays—are reasonable, the proposed solution is not, in any way, and will be discriminatory toward a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing the transport of goods by road, or if that was not the objective, has proven to be the outcome.

Esteemed members, this proposal is untimely and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transportation, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of

Individuals in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their end consumer, a consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these tariffs.
Your Excellency, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally respectful transportation system, bypassing the highway, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
European networks, the motorways of the sea, and border connections remain, in some cases, projects and not reality.
Sir, when the Titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, let alone to play for joy.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on 15 July 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European External Action Service on October 13th recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, awaiting the Parliament’s opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that already in the seventh meeting of the Parliamentary Mita Commission of the European Union of Mexico, held at the end of October of last year, we stated that a
A Strategic Association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We noted the opportune timing of relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current global agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, particularly in light of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis affecting our continents.

With the great nation that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of governance, a commitment to gender equality, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and the respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations regarding the Strategic Association European Union of Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
Regarding the report on microcredit, I would like to congratulate all the speakers, as they have done a remarkable job.
Improved, without doubt, the Commission’s initiative.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to form the basis for developing a genuine framework within the European Union for the microcredit sector, a sector

I believe it has been successful in many developing countries, and even in some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as an instrument for improving social inclusion and job creation.

But it hadn’t been transferred to the sector or the community context. And I believe that’s an opportunity to do so, particularly starting from the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
It is, therefore, a priority to reinforce the initiatives advanced here, but further progress is needed.
Funding for this microcredit support structure must be increased.
It is necessary to facilitate availability for individuals and companies that lack access to loans, and in that sense, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of
The European Guarantee for Microcredit Loans as an instrument that can facilitate that access and which has been included in the report.
And I conclude that, without a doubt, this will lay the groundwork for us to establish a harmonious framework within the European context that promotes the microcredit sector.
Madam President, while we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of aid for coal, an essential indigenous energy source.

And I say this with the foresight of experience, because inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed themselves to express a contrary view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
It will be necessary to continue supporting my country’s coal after 2012, and I want that recorded in the session minutes.
Officials, confine yourselves to complying with the current plan and, subsequently, starting in 2012, with the instrument that we will begin negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bokland has explained, is very timely given the Diplomatic Conference on the Ship Recycling Convention that will be held next May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Bloán not only on the question but also on the resolution he has prepared.

Within the People's Party, we support the fight against improper practices and methods used to undervalue ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brokland's proposed resolution. However, there are some points that concern us.

The first is section 3, which he also pointed out, stating that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section, because there are different interpretations both within and outside the European Union, and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and should not contradict it, but the future international agreement on ship dismantling should define the details of its application.
The draft resolution also requests, in its point a, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us rather premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time, when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what system will be adopted for this financing. And I believe that the European Commission also does not have a clear answer regarding this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
We do not believe it is the Commission’s purview to decide this, which should also be determined in an international Agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence regarding the future Convention on Recycling of Ships (G) and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, and all of this, taking into account not only the Basel Convention, but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a strong agreement regarding this program, and congratulate us all, because in times of economic crisis it is fundamental to maintain a program like this with clear positive social effects.

although we are faced with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these moments of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned or
concerned about the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those most in need—the poorest in the European Union—must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here we concur with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a distinct social character, but because it is a functional instrument, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, as is the case with the rapporteur, we oppose this program being treated as confidential between the European Union and the Member States, as this would constitute discrimination among States based on their wealth, with the possibility that the program could not be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is understood that now, when assistance is most needed, there is a desire to save community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
Forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand greater effort and, in no case, a reduction in budgetary expenditure.
Austerity, yes, but not for the most vulnerable.
It is precisely to guarantee that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of distributed foods.

Therefore, from the Socialist group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food should preferably be community-sourced and of high quality.
a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs, which we recently discussed in this chamber, such as the school fruit scheme.
That is all, and many thanks.
We hope that the committee will take this parliament’s position into consideration when voting and, above all, that the plan is implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions of our planet.
The consequences of an unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thaw of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making a new, globally-reaching regulation necessary to protect the Arctic, similar to the one already in place for the Antarctic, even taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is necessary, among all parties involved, including, without doubt, the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and to multilaterally regulate navigation through the new sea routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in managing common problems.

In these moments of difficulty and uncertainty, we must elevate that spirit and alignment to prevent states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical rivalries, forgetting what should be the common objective: the preservation of a vast, shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of those who have spoken.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it is said that we need to seek a more intelligent model for doing business, what is actually being discussed is abolishing intellectual property.
Business can only be conducted if there is an established right.
You already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under Mr. Macrivy’s division, has adopted a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the Chamber should approve the commitment that we have.
achieved within the remit of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms. McGull and Mr. Tubón.
I believe it is a magnificent Directive, a Directive that will boost the creation of intellectual property.
And, furthermore, that Directive includes several recommendations with respect to the continuation of the work.

I believe that approval by this Chamber will harmonize and I hope that the Council aligns its lines with those of the Commission and the Parliament, will serve to ensure that in the next legislature the

May the Commission continue down this path, making proposals to the Parliament, and let us advance in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr. President, the information you provide is correct, but the impression we, the European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens, have is that there is a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this moment, as fiscal demands are reinforced in each of the Member States, mobility is nearly impossible.
And when we ask the Commission the reason for the pragmatic approach, it is because the Commission never finds support in the Council.

This is a sort of vicious circle whereby the liaison refers us to the Council, and the Council refers us to the commission. However, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe that we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relationships as a consequence of the heavy fiscal burden that a lack of fiscal harmonization can entail.
Can the Council do anything to help us break this vicious cycle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the headline isn't about Mr. Tajani’s arrival, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of having been a parliamentarian and European official.
As a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that Members of the European Parliament have regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to fault the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is to say, the Commission has only a few officials at headquarters where complaints are received and they have some possibilities for action. But, at this moment, furthermore, the trend is to limit budgetary powers, with which the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law. All application of Community law is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, in this regard, I don't believe we can demand too much of the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission. And I believe that in Mrs. Frazoni’s report, there are some points that can be useful in achieving this application.
I refer to those relating to the coordination of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission led by my colleague, my companion from this very group, Mariaán, I had the opportunity to visit.
And of being present in this court and of being aware of the immense work that this court was undertaking, not only for Sierra Leone but for all of humanity.
the special court of Sierra Lea, as I have already told you, has undoubtedly set a precedent.

A precedent, because, as the Resolution rightly indicates, the international Prime, financed by voluntary contributions, is the first court established in the country where the alleged crimes occurred, and it is also the first court, as has already been noted, to try a former prime minister.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but because it serves as a reference for other tribunals that have been established in its wake, such as Rwanda, Antigua Yugoslavia, Cambodia, or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this Resolution be approved, on which we have been working jointly with the tribunal for several months.
Two years ago, we approved a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of
money and did not have sufficient support; we must thank the European Commission here as well for stepping in with, let's say, financial support for this tribunal.

Now, above all else, we request two things first: that convicted individuals serve their sentences. Not only the functioning of the Tribunal, which will end next year, is at stake, but also the legacy that this Tri is going to leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by greater funding.
Ultimately, the Sierra Leone Special Court is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have judged war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us. In it, upon entering the courtroom, we observed a motto written that read, "Without justice, there is no peace."
Precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation—not only as Europeans but as human beings—to ensure that the legacy of this Tribunal remains permanent in history.

The final maritime package represents a success for this Parliament and for the European Union across its three institutions and justifies, once again, the codecision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all citizens of the European Union.
I was a minute short. Before that, I want to respond to the lady commissioner, who is aware of my friendship and affection for her, and, indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the police commissioner has not said a single word about the Ombudsman's recommendation.

I don't even want to hear from Mrs. Cúva, because evidently she is not the one who possesses the data. But all the data she has given me is consistent with what we knew and with the fact that the ombudsman is also aware and isn’t telling us whether, indeed

Despite all of that, and as the Public Defender, who is aware of this, recommends changing the regulation, he does not state whether the Commission will accept what the Public Defender requests and what the Parliament recommends based on the Public Defender’s request.
Mr. President, I believe the proposed regulations submitted to the committee are important and necessary. Furthermore, it was also important and necessary that from the

We in the European Parliament would reiterate the principles upon which both Members of the European Parliament, Mr. Viesca and Mr. Deré, have insisted – namely, the principle of Community competence.

This concerns a matter of community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to retain certain powers for the Member States, but, as Mr. Barrot has stated, limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is unavailable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament have the authority to relinquish those community competences.

Having established this, we are dealing with an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, moving forward and starting from this point, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary—as, for example, Mr. Sogor emphasized in his most recent intervention.
We are discussing the problems that most directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve those people’s problems, people will realize that the European Union has a function.
In conclusion, Mr. President, to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. de Breya, Honorable Members, and to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and requested to intervene in this matter because I was a witness to what was termed an expulsion, but in reality, it was a kidnapping of our colleague, Luis Herrero.

Moreover, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of the opposition, threats, disregard for human dignity, and manipulative use of the justice system are standard practice in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel’s back and that has given rise to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his, cited in the Resolution, and others that are not.

As is the case with Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well-known for its danger and, furthermore, because he voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied thanks to the assistance of others and, specifically, Citibank, and managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and furthermore, later lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas prison and illegally, having been detained for two years without any lacking charges.
Their only crime was being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is that of Nison Moreno, a student leader from the Universidad de los Andes, elected on several occasions to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2013 elections against the current Minister of Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of homicide, in the frustrated stage, violent lewd acts, and all of this despite having been cleared of previous charges.

Situations like yours are the daily reality in this country where the persecution of opponents, with the intent of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent, have become commonplace occurrences.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be defeated at the ballot box.

Madam President, Commissioner, indeed, it is undeniable that progress has been made recently, but, despite all that has been achieved, the southern part of the Union is burning and burning increasingly so.
Therefore, the resolution approved by this Parliament cannot be merely a resolution serving to highlight the great concern caused to us by the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, irrespective of any responsibilities that may exist in certain States or in certain autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act with swiftness and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are considerable.
Neither the victims, nor the damages suffered, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy, nor can they comprehend budgetary shortfalls.

Prioritization is necessary, and action must be taken. And action, in this case, involves modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventative policies, demanding compliance.

In case, responsibilities to States lacking them. But assuming this is not a problem for some Southern European States, and that climate change does not affect only some States. It affects everyone and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the primary tasks facing this Parliament in the near term must be to ensure that the European Union secures clear commitments at the next Copenhagen Summit.

Robust measures to maximize the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, because, evidently, they are at the root of the fires, their causes, and these, in turn, are the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge facing this Parliament, with all certainty.
But let that challenge set by the Commission be fulfilled, if, truly, Commissioner, you want to prevent the south of the Union – which does exist – from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I address Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have followed you with great interest and with considerable respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have me utterly astonished at present.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have demonstrated a disdain toward the Group in which I am present, the Group of Non-Affiliates, not conceiving of dedicating even a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have demonstrated a disregard for all of our electors.

Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role that the CAP plays in addressing the need for food supply on an international scale.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget – something that needs to be said very clearly, namely that the CAP is no longer a priority – but food sufficiency should be. And in past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Therefore, agriculture cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy capable of thriving in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to ensure the viability of his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient, high-quality food to an increasingly demanding consumer.
Therefore, I believe that a change of direction in the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) would need to occur, but not its disappearance.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to re-establishing a market management policy that provides greater price stability, which would have a positive impact not only on farmers but also on consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of best practices to foster balanced relationships among the different actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a more equitable distribution of commercial margins.

Furthermore, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union regulations regarding the environment.

According to a United Nations report, in 2009 approximately 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union be based primarily on the protection of victims, with particular attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to passively witness this spectacle, this display of sexual exploitation unfolding before our eyes.
Therefore, I fully support this Parliament's request that assistance to victims be unconditional, and that penalties be more stringent and harsher, as Mr. Barrot just stated.
Having said this, I would like to request the President and the Council to utilize all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to fruition, will be an effective instrument in the fight against these crimes.

I anticipate a firm commitment, as we have already seen from the Spanish Presidency, to ensure that this order offers victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems of our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely grave problem of human trafficking, and that we do not remain merely offering fine words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which resonated so profoundly and inspired such hope for the peoples of the world and for the most promising of international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the irreverence towards political and conscientious prisoners, the irreverence against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco, with the mistreatment of political prisoners he also considered common, his own obsessive disdain for the exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco and all enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be supportive of those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who undermine freedoms.

Never again shall we permit a person who was fighting for their rights and the rights of all to die in a Cuban prison or any other place, without our voice rising strong and steadfast, demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old Afro-Cuban bricklayer, who was merely requesting improvements to prison conditions, died after six days of a hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And in those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, abandoned by his jailers; it must be remembered, amidst all of this, a dense silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists are now on hunger strike, including psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Last week, the National Woman's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union, stating that violence against women can be eradicated.

Today we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems reasonable to acknowledge that Mexican women, both Indigenous and non-Indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or the police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, to date the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and therefore it is correctly spoken of a near-absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat feminicides—a harsh but accurate term—when we see that almost the entirety of murders committed against women remain unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico is that, in the last four years, only 11 of the criminals who murdered nearly seven women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two Indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and until
Now more than three years have passed in prison, for it was they who were alone during an incident in a market, six men from the Federal Investigation Agency.

As he was unable to do on March 11th, International Day of Victims of Terrorism, he wishes today, from this Parliament, to pay them a well-deserved tribute, one that recognizes the immense sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin work on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the forgotten ones and bear the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their perpetrators.
It is now time for these European institutions to recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and to assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

That will honor all those who make it possible, and that the first article be that support for victims of terrorism shall be recognized as having the right to justice, and that no government ever pay a political price.

There is a call to everyone who can defend victims so they never forget that true peace is the one that is born from justice, and that is the only peace we, who believe in it, must defend from Europe and from any place in the world.

Mr. President, it has been necessary, sir, to find ourselves on the brink of an abyss and an economic collapse for heads of state and government to understand that the path forward is not one of greater nationalism but one of greater Europe.
At this juncture, measures have been implemented, such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the nascent form of a European public treasury.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have become aware that we are all navigating the same vessel and that addressing individual situations is futile, and moreover, doing so in an ad hoc manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, conversely, the beginning of a genuine European economic government. Because what is lacking, dear colleagues, is authentic governance; what is missing is authentic government, if we want to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, incidentally, nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, reinforcing the European Commission and reinforcing this Parliament is the only sound recipe for building a Europe that, otherwise, would vanish like a fleeting shadow.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a Regulation of utmost importance to both consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is by no means easy to achieve a balanced labeling system that contains everything essential, but is not so exhaustive as to complicate the information.
This is an excellent report, and the speaker will be commended for it.
I concur with her on the major topics pertaining to nutritional information and the controversial matter of profiles, especially if we take into account that the Commission did not fulfill the
The commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their terms of use before January 19, 2009, as stipulated by Regulation 19 24 2006.

There is a matter that concerns me, and it is the possibility of consistency in national regulations for labeling, because it runs counter to the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the absence of an indication, it could mislead the consumer.
Furthermore, voluntary labeling is always planned.
Going further can entail economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any significant, clear benefit to the consumer.
Regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission’s proposal aligns with the existing Directive, which has functioned well and has not presented any problems.
Reopening this debate could prove both dangerous and necessary, and create difficulties for the circulation of the product.
Mr. President, the best demonstration of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the full session.

However, in addition to good will, I believe we must be practical about how we label foods if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect from the one we pursue, that is, confusing the consumer instead of helping them to become informed.
It is not a matter of illustrating, but of preventing, of informing about what one can eat and to what extent.
It is necessary to label regarding fats, regarding sugars, regarding trans fats.
indeed
Indeed, regarding that which affects cholesterol, concerning all those substances that affect what we have discussed: obesity, health, people.

, but other foods, with other information such as the place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion or, for example, in meat, stating the place of birth, the place of transit, the grazing place, the place of slaughter of the cattle, can illustrate a great deal, but they will ultimately cause confusion.

It is up to us to ensure that we are practical and that this Regulation is remembered as the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, conversely, as the one that will further confuse them and impose matters that, far from achieving better health outcomes, will result in greater confusion.

Therefore, I request, for example, that some of us choose the GDA—the amount of daily intake—instead of the traffic light system, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will be nearing the limit; therefore, consume only one.
