It is also important to consider the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the principal figures in that Spanish agreement, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8th.
The change then insisted on the need to extend conciliation at the European scale and on the need to have the voice and initiatives of trade unions in this our Europe.
So it must be.
Mr. President, setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union unfortunately moves in response to emergency situations such as a grave
tempted a massive influx of immigrants, as is currently occurring in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens toward the Italian coast could result in a chronicle of a foretold death.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our conscience, on that of all those who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
It may occur to us to shake our heads, but the next day we will forget and

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream while European countries do not commit to sufficient economic means for it to be effective.
Speaking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do they really believe that Frontex can currently guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future in Europe, but rather in their own countries, for that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when discussing a common European migration policy, more necessary than ever today.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is noteworthy that in OECD countries, the highest indices of income equity among citizens are found in the area of pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost only 20% of their value in 2008, and that they continue to remain far from the solvency levels required to this day.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unfeasible reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be achieved in a transversal manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies regarding birth rates or work-life balance.

Ambitious policies regarding access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration, which also, from a demographic perspective, guarantee the sustainability of our pensions.

Finally, I regret that the text does not establish limits on the abuse of the status of self-employed workers (pecas) within companies, as, as a general rule, these are excluded from all types of social security contributions.

In my view, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers to whom, if more is being demanded to secure a dignified pension, it would also be necessary to make it less difficult to access decent employment.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we find ourselves at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion seeks a harmonious development among territories to ensure that their citizens can fully leverage their unique territorial characteristics.
However, achieving this objective also requires advancing cooperation among regions of the Union facing similar challenges and issues.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union's Strategy for the Atlantic region, a shared perspective for addressing the common challenges faced by the region's States, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is aligned with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union’s policies for the post-2013 period, particularly regional policy and maritime policy.
But, Honorable Members, it is first and foremost necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multilevel governance, founded on a closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to discuss gender equality, as we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who a hundred years ago fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have made significant progress in these one hundred years, but much remains to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and the discrimination of women is a real fact.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and my hope to all the women who in the North African Revolution are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half as much as a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere else in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it. And as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many may not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half as much as men, and that domestic violence disproportionately affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce these events in this Parliament, and of course, I promise I will continue working.
Mr. President, I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the deputies who have spoken this morning here and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on whether the European Council is willing to acknowledge the role of the institutions mentioned.
Because the new mechanism, regarding which we are speaking, must be an important component of the economic engine driven by a European Union.
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is to say, this effort in which we are engaged must be avoided at all costs from ending in the intergovernmental track, which is a dead end or the track of the dominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Esteemed colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this [initiative/achievement/etc.] is among those that reinforce and balance this delicate edifice.
There remain essential points for improvement, therefore we must return the report to the Commission.
It does not end here, as the parliamentary leader of this report.
The initial proposal was poor.
That is what consumer associations at both the national and European levels were telling us.
And I particularly esteem the work of the Consumers’ Union of Asturias and its indefatigable president, Dacia Olso.
We have succeeded in having the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4 rejected.

It must be stated plainly that maximum harmonization when establishing the same protection in all Member States would entail a reduction in the protection afforded to many consumers, since in various countries there is a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, however, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of clauses they consider unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Shift the burden of proof to the individual clauses, so that merchants must demonstrate that the clauses deviating from the generally established terms have been individually negotiated, and that contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and readily comprehensible manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization with regard to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79 percent of retailers believe that full harmonization in this area will have little to no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Ms. Gerhard for the excellent work done.
And a general reflection.
It's not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that the aim is to avoid curtailing existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between companies and consumers, we must
Establish simultaneously a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance requires agreeing to a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot permit the adoption of a community rule to mean the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I welcome the improvement in negotiations within the European Parliament, but I wish to insist that rights already established should not be reduced.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis, and that, either we are not doing the necessary work to prevent it, or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to prevent it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is issuing a call for everyone to make a small gesture in the interest of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will follow suit.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue depending on energies that are not its own, that are distant, or on insecure energies.
that helps states build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new
We must also support raising awareness of new consumption guidelines, because renewables and efficiencies are, without a doubt, the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to make a call to all countries of the Union to join that call—that willingness of five states, including Spain—to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because in doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a leader in innovation, freedom, and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the planet’s sustainability.
Madam, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and once again I am here to combat it.

I must say that I not only do not tire of them, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best.

I have this platform available to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, as legislators, to compel the States to punish aggressors, in accordance with the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that one in four European women has experienced gender-based violence at least once in their lifetime, and that children, to an equal extent, have also been affected, I believe it is impossible not to demand greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to continue insisting time and again on weaving in the victims, as we have already done in the European Organisation for the Protection of Victims, of which I was rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed considerable consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that when addressing domestic violence affecting all members of the
Family, children, elderly people, women, and men should not be a cause for political opportunism, as it behooves us all to advance the resolution of this social scourge.
First, one must not remain silent, and second, one must get to work, since, although we have been discussing gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something must be going wrong, and therefore, it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to actions, providing the necessary aid and resources so that women can live with dignity and security.
May all victims know that I will always be here, continuing to lend them my voice until we all succeed in defeating this.
enemy that tragically ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough now, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Mr. President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner, I concur with you that we must listen to citizens and restore trust in the European project.
Therefore, today can be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

Because, with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving forward toward the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for progress toward greater Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy, fostering sustainable growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthening their social rights.
Finally, I would like to request that the Commission submit these proposals as soon as possible.
The blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, consequently, to our public health.

A disease against which we were fighting through the activated vaccine, the use of which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal circulation, because the use of these vaccines can provoke an undesired circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine was limited, restricting vaccination in the area where animals had previously been found infected, thereby creating a double disadvantage for ranchers: the disease itself, and the restrictions.

But all these problems appear to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new, broader strategies—strategies that address the truly essential aspects of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all of these reasons, it is of vital importance to this sector that we modify the Directive to permit its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Your Excellency, compliance with our treaties, particularly regarding the correspondence tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into effect before summer, because our delay, and your delay, would only be harming the livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has undertaken following the complaint presented by FPEex, which is the Spanish Organization of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of that report are perfectly clear and more than justify the fact that the European Commission, had it started working on this much earlier to clarify the operation of the pricing system – at least with regard to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to resolve potential loopholes that the incoming price regulation may give rise to, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without previously addressing the shortcomings of the current import regime.
Lord, it is now time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and begin investigating where fraud occurs, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that, in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without resolving the details that we have outlined.

Our objective is not to hinder the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that said agreements do not severely harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

Regarding the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed-upon measures will take place, and this is only possible through the reform of the current import pricing system.
Until we have a new system of entry prices, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will be able to ratify that agreement which the commission has already finalized.

Furthermore, if control is the responsibility of the Member States, a significant economic effort should be demanded of them. But it is also true that we have been advocating for a long time for a European customs frontier system, following the same model as the United States, to ensure that effective control.

Mr. President, Commissioner, addressing this report in Parliament has been complex, primarily because it has involved these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal sent by the Commission to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan. We propose that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided that they take into account the sensitivities of the
European industry, and especially the textile sector, which in regions like the Valencian Community in Spain are severely affected by the crisis.

However, this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade likely cannot be addressed with the urgency these acts require, so we must learn from this for the future.

To Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission’s original proposals, as they do not take into account the effects on the European industry regarding the implementation timelines for sensitive products.
I would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not align with the pending text expected to be approved by the WTO. We would be out of time.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal, and we regret that we must vote no.
Mr. President, I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating everyone who has made reaching an agreement possible.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves on, because it affects the daily life of all citizens. But with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few observations.
First, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and consistent information.
For consumers, regarding the components of textile products. Extensive information will be of no use if citizens are subsequently unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary, but insufficient step. We should advance further and protect citizens who may be more vulnerable.
Your Lordship, it is imperative to establish a European sizing labeling system based on body dimensions, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing an item of clothing is the size.
Therefore, we should be far more ambitious and seek the harmonization of sizes.
Mr. President, three observations regarding the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and hold great affection for that country, but it is evident that German authorities have acted with haste and imprudence in this case.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European action, we observe that the one developed by the Securitymentia Authority and by the Commission has been lackluster, very subdued, and imprecise. It has not known how to coordinate nor direct.
zero, those harmed have the right to prompt economic compensation.
But, for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organize, in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, a large exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.

One must reclaim lost honor, a phrase pleasing to the German writer Heinrich Bell.
One must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for it.
Mr. President, it is first obligatory to express my sincere sorrow for the twenty-three victims already deceased, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
This crisis must be said to be the most compelling evidence that the European Union needs to significantly improve its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The member states involved have demonstrated slowness, ineffectiveness, and non-functionality. And at this stage, even after 23 deaths, we still do not know where the problem originates.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present, leading to cases of economic ruin and job destruction that formerly were

unemployment shelters, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population, because while you, from the Commission, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities

very ill-informed and quite irresponsible Germans, with names and surnames of Spanish farms, meanwhile the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it; the citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council, being held in Luxembourg at two o’clock in the afternoon, propose to the ministers that a portion of the 2.5 billion euros existing as unutilized carryover funds from the common agricultural policy be used.
those two thousand million euros to repair as much as possible the damage caused.

To that end, it is necessary to seek a legal loophole, one that permits it, a legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as in the case of mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, commissioners, ministers, today in Luxembourg you must be equal to your responsibility.

German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations leveled, should support this economic solution without doubt and from the outset, and also finance, with their own funds, communication campaigns to re-establish consumer trust lost in self-produced goods.

Mr. President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the deceased, and I hope that what is being done will prevent more deaths and halt the chain of suffering endured by those who did nothing to deserve it.

We do not know the causes, certainly, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions, and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state of another continent.

The arrogance displayed by Mrs. Merkel and her Minister of Health in frequently addressing other states, had it been translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordinating, some of the events that have transpired would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a State, which has been the Spanish State, and for the most important sector of agriculture, and has led to the family ruin of thousands of people and small business owners, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I request that you go to the Council and demand total compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for the lives of the deceased.
that the control systems be reviewed.
And that accountability be demanded of Mrs. Merkel.
that less arrogance and more diligence be requested of him.
And let him be held accountable for the damages he has caused.
You cannot ignore the fact that Hamburg lies within your state.
He cannot ignore his responsibilities.
It cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to inflict the damage it has caused.

A bit more humility, a bit more sound management, and a bit less conservatism would have served well to prevent this crisis from slipping through their hands and to ensure that Spain and other farmers in the south would not have to suffer its grievous consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because we are requesting it of you, Commissioner, of the Council, and of the German State, here in Spain.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem before an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response, someone has been sought to blame, whether or not they caused it.

The system has not worked. We have twenty dead, 1600 affected, and we still do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a principle of precaution—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
Two were not contaminated. I repeat this because contrary versions have been heard here.
But so you can understand the importance of what these words have generated, three hundred thousand jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, it knows no borders; we are requesting accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has a greater number of affected individuals, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
And what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers do today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

It is my responsibility to report to German authorities that they unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically, the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería—which were model farms—and that they will not recover from those accusations.
Thousands of families without work wonder why—why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will quickly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, request economic, immediate, and moral measures for all producers – from Andalusia and from across Europe – who look to us with indignation, but with hope.
Rather than prioritizing research and European collaboration, German authorities have defamed and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
The treatment of the southern countries by Mrs. Merkel regarding both agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Deauwe and Col.
None of that lacks moral credit.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, among other countries, share our reservations in readily accepting the so-called Euro-sketch.

The coincidence stems from our condition as peripheral countries, for whom, ultimately, the burden of this singular levy will fall—a levy to be collected by the States of the European Union possessing geographical centrality.
The rationale inspiring the Eurovignette is beset by significant contradictions, and the supporting discourse grows increasingly fragile.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, ultimately, it does not hold that, in order to alleviate congestion, only vehicles of a specific configuration should be penalized, leaving passenger cars excluded, in the same way that the old principle of “the polluter pays” is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Roviñeta, which was envisioned as a source of infrastructure funding, ultimately, will only allocate 15% to the financing of European networks and not in a mandatory manner.

but rather as a simple recommendation, in such a way that the minister of finance on duty will decide how the funds are allocated to the purpose he deems most suitable for the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing more than another blow to the transportation of goods by road, which, as things stand today, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is far more stark in a crisis of economic hardship.

In that sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot permit experiments that could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy with the imposition of new added costs.

The food crisis recklessly imposed upon Spanish products has resulted in an unfair penalty and substantial losses for those penalized by the oruroñeza – carriers of goods and farmers of premium crops.
These are the reasons, esteemed members, why the Spanish Federation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft initiative.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that upon assuming the presidency of this session, I wish to express my sorrow and deep regret at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred just a few hours ago at the age of 87.

We celebrate Jorge Serunun, who was imprisoned in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable, committed writer, a particular contributor to our program, The European Book of the Year, and we celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death as a companion and friend, and I will ask President Buzek to convey a message of sincere condolences and solidarity to his family and the Government of Spain, which I am certain we all share here.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We cannot continue to turn a blind eye.
It is inconsistent to have a single currency and, at the same time, lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency demands.

Specifically, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a resounding no to competition between the debt issuances of the individual states, and the creation of a genuine European public treasury.
harmonization of tax policies that guarantee the equality of citizens, combat fiscal fraud, and help to define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, it will be said, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated, because no one listens to them.
And precisely because of not listening, those dark times of which the poet Bertolbrecht spoke are unfolding.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument to reduce development disparities between regions and Member States.
At the same time, we can reclaim the positive image of Europe that citizens have recently come to associate only with stringent austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of European solidarity and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to consider the needs and characteristics

geographical features of the regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. zero, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds so that the regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding abrupt changes in the provision of aid, and fourth, foster a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, authorities are implementing stringent austerity measures.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I urge the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The President of the Tribunal stated that I was chosen to support the peace process and that, to my knowledge, there exists in Spain a terrorist organization called ETA which, to this day, has not abandoned arms and which two months ago managed to have its political arm, Bildu, govern, among other municipalities, San Sebastián.
I do not believe that from Europe we should give a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to apportion blame between victims and perpetrators.
Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Certainly, not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues, such as Mayor Oreja and Turgáis, Salva, or myself, must be accompanied by security.
I believe the culture of life is not one of shooting, the
True culture cannot exist without freedom.
No and a thousand times no.
When San Sebastián becomes a city free for all, it should resubmit its candidacy, and while learning the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow perhaps they will deserve it, but today with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided in drafting this document.
I say the same regarding the other deputies and colleagues of this Parliament’s Committee.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. Nothing could be more fitting to commemorate this event than to debate now the energy infrastructures in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its common internal market policy, the promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument in the fight against climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.

In the Treaty of Lisbon, a section has been dedicated to energy, article 21, where these commitments I have mentioned are formulated, and furthermore, the promotion of interconnection of energy networks.

Consequently, the objective of the report we have prepared is oriented toward rectifying energy infrastructures that, in the judgment of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we observe a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, with the immense potential of renewable energy in the south of
Europe and in North Africa, with the problems arising from large-scale electricity storage, with the needs for recharging electric vehicles, among others, many urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to confront today if we do not devise new networks and new connections both within the European Union and with third countries.

Therefore, in these coming years, it concerns advancing the determination of the necessary infrastructures, by establishing the criteria that will allow for the selection of projects of European interest.
eliminating the energy islands C, ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes, and arbitrating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the
regulatory authorizations and licenses in the Member States, ensuring funding that attracts and stimulates private investment without prejudice to public support that is necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
It has been posited that, through the reduction of energy demand, dependence on imports can be lessened with the consequent impact on infrastructure needs.
The primary concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to enable the execution of the necessary works.
Currently, they are prolonged indefinitely.
And they were halted by the opposition of populations to seeing towers or facilities of another type grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to providing early information to citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that authorities in a State fail to address a request within a reasonable timeframe.
We face ambitious objectives for which the collaboration of all is necessary.
In this regard, companies in the sector are indispensable, rightfully calling for a stable regulatory framework, the best way to ensure funding for their efforts.
Until now, the European Union’s energy policy, both towards external borders and within its own territory, has lacked a distinctly European impetus.
to speak with a single voice, a voice that is clearly audible and resonates fully within the European Union building, because it is from our energy fragility that we have
to muster the strength to build a Europe that is energetically robust and vigorous, a worthy successor this year of anniversary to that great invention that was the CECA, our cradle, precisely.
Mr. President, whenever there is a commitment that allows progress, one must congratulate oneself, but I do not believe that the commitment we have reached is cause for dying of a fit of happiness.
We must be prudent in the moments of happiness we seize.

It is true that we have made especially significant progress regarding food labeling, particularly with respect to ensuring the clarity of the message. However, we have fallen short in the area of trans fats and, for example, the obligation to label them.
What I do want to request of the Commission is that it not miss the deadlines.

In a continent as well-supplied as this, with problems of overeating, cardiac issues stemming from excess weight, it is necessary to expedite and to propose, as soon as possible, the prohibition of adding trans fats to foods, as has been done in Denmark, as is being done in Spain, as has been done in Australia.
Without delay and without waiting any longer.
The commitments will depend on the speed with which we implement, the clarity with which we develop, and how ambitious we are.
We do not want to revel in the rush of happiness for what we have done, because it is good, but not something to celebrate exuberantly.
Let us advance further and be more precise, regarding all the matters that have been pointed out to him.
I wanted to say to everyone that there is only one kind of terrorism. There is only that terrorism which destroys the lives of innocents. It doesn't matter from where it comes.
The victims of terrorism, whom I represent, because the terrorist organization murdered my brother and his wife, share a common thread and, in the name of

Account audits today are burdened by the concentration of firms and the lack of auditor independence, and they do not contribute to generating that much-desired trust that would revitalize our economy.
It would not be unreasonable to consider eliminating the legal obligation for account audits.
Why not?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and within the markets, we must undertake a profound reform of audits to ensure they represent a genuine added value and not merely a legal burden.
Large auditing firms leverage auditing services as a calling card for prospective clients.
Once familiar with the company, they offer more tailored complementary services to often compensate for the low prices of strict auditing.
We have a price distortion problem in the sector.

These complementary services now account for almost 50% of billing, so large audit firms do not want to lose auditing services, but not for the audit itself, but rather to maintain and increase complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four large entities that dominate European markets by over 90%.
As such an oligopoly, they control prices and establish barriers to entry for new competitors, leveraging intangibles such as international brand image.

It is true that this brand image can be based on dietary advantages, but it does not always imply greater efficiency given the diversity of accounting legislation in the States subject to particular treatment in each Member State.
I share the objectives of the Green Book, the independence and consolidation of the sector, and the means to be utilized: rotation and joint audits.
Bidding, reinforcement of professional skepticism, substance over form, segregation of audit services from non-audit services.
I have attempted to incorporate them into my report to the extent that parliamentary majorities and the report’s modest scope have allowed.

Honorable members, this is nothing more than a small step towards achieving new legislation that will cleanse the field of audits of the iron elements that have led us to this terrible economic crisis.

The Directive on the rights of victims of crime, including terrorism, and as a Spaniard, having directly suffered the cruelty of the terrorist organization ETA, I wish to thank President Busek for his support of my country and its victims.

I understand the satisfaction of many at this new statement from ETA, but I must remind you that we cannot yet ring the bells, because to this day they have not handed over the weapons, nor have they dissolved, nor have they asked for forgiveness from their victims.
It is also important for Your Lordships to know that in Spain, we do not need to reach any peace between two factions, because there has been no war.
My brother, Alberto Jiménez Becerril, murdered by ETA in Seville alongside his wife, was not returning from war; he was going home to his three children, who would never see him again.
We have the obligation to explain to my brother's children that their parents were better than those who murdered them.
If we accept an outcome without victors or vanquished, we will be teaching those children that political objectives can be achieved through killing.

Therefore, I request the support of this Chamber so that it is not deceived by the terrorists of this group and their accomplices, and that it listens to the sincere voices of the victims, who desire nothing more than the peace born of justice.

primarily, they are Moroccan tomatoes.

Peaks where the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish to pay today tribute to all the women who, despite the significant progress we have made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and improved working conditions, I believe that women’s equality remains very distant.
Today, women can work without having to ask permission from anyone, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
It is also necessary to remember the women in rural areas whose work is overlooked.
I believe another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Already this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to exert physical or psychological violence upon them.
And now is the time to say it low and to say it loud and clear.

From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Order for the Protection of Victims and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which, God willing, will be voted on next June.
We must also say, and I would like to reiterate, that motherhood remains an obstacle to women's advancement, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope, and with many women, with the help of increasingly more men, we must advance on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights, and also of duties.
We have come a long way, but there is much more to do.
I must admit that I do not absolutely and profoundly believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree.
Many of my colleagues, and of course, with Mrs. Reding, initiated this debate and advanced this path so that women reclaim the place they deserve, and you can count on my support for that.

Mr. President, at a juncture of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting both public health and in which, as in the community where I live, research centers like Príncipe Felipe, specializing in diabetes, are being left without funding, this Resolution comes at the most opportune time; it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a recommendation from the Council stating that Member States must increase research, even with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs promoting healthy eating and lifestyles.

In sum, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigate, coordinate, and implement national programs coordinated by the Commission and demanding results. Regarding diabetes, it is essential to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and ensure their very lives.

If we dedicate more money to this, some will take a little longer to be reimbursed, but assuredly, those who currently have problems will experience a better quality of life, and we—as States, as Council, and as Commission—will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to safeguard the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many matters that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market, a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. That is, this price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all of the European Union’s green policy.
If emission rights are not valued, it incentivizes increased emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and worse yet.
Funding for significant projects will be jeopardized, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage facilities.
This is the risk.
It falls to us, to the Commission, and to the Parliament to swear it.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.

The cases, however, are of urgent necessity.
The deputies verified this firsthand during a trip to the Palestinian refugee camps in Iraq, in Syria. Also, the news that reached us shortly from Tunisia.
Another institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tabares, there are many good parliamentarians, but few with such tenacity as Ruiz.
Mr. Tas has fought to ensure that the European Parliament retains the new powers gained following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the constant work that GNUR has undertaken, without which its success would also have been impossible.
AgNUR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope we can also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package next month.

The European social model we so proudly champion is not solely founded on our pension systems, education, or healthcare, but also on a particular understanding of the balance between employer and worker within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish government without dialogue or consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 strategy, both in terms of job creation and the quality of employment itself.
Labor reform alone does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define under what conditions workers enter companies, under what conditions they remain in them, and under what conditions they leave them.
And with this reform, 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective bargaining agreements, where they can be dismissed due to a decline in company revenues or
They may unilaterally modify their schedules; what is clear is that workers will enter the labor market with greater instability, remain in it with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which undermines the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike such as the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt ambitious measures to guarantee fiscal consolidation and lay the groundwork for improvements in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's projections, incidentally from yesterday, admit—to the IMF itself—that they predate the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish Government presently.

Other measures that we have adopted within the General State Budgets for 2012 which, in our judgment, will guarantee that the deficit target is met this year. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability is being finalized this month.

An education reform in healthcare will be presented, involving an adjustment of one billion euros. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to the need for financial institutions to provide an additional sixty million.
summary, Spain is meeting the goals set by the Union and the goals set by the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary for all of us to save ourselves, and for Spain, with everyone, without any doubt, and no criticisms from one side or the other contribute to this. Either we are all the countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and the new path, or it will be difficult for us to move forward in the terms outlined by the Commission.
You want to make me, sir Rajoy, the president of the government, the protagonist.
I approve, I would have no objection.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance ever had any government.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to frame the issue.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond that, with that significant European value, which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.

European institutions have outstanding legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments within Community law, whether original or derived, to counteract the arbitrariness of Argentinian authorities.
I am a modest professor of public law and offer my services to them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

on edges in the economic sphere, in the social sphere, and also in the environmental sphere; it is important to maintain those equilibria that will allow us to advance further in the environmental realm, yes, but which also do not harm the economy and do not create greater social crises than those we are already experiencing.

first the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component linked now to the drafting and compliance with energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas and the incorporation of the
agriculture within sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also access the deductions permitted within the CO2 emissions bracket.

We are experiencing a significant controversy that has austerity and growth as indispensable reference points.
If one hears the noise that is forming, it would seem that the idea of growth is a luminous invention of these days.
Nothing further from reality.
In Europe, a pact specifically named the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since 1997.

Therefore, a significant portion of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as those concerning regional cohesion and research, are growth-oriented policies that pursue the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest opportunity to be heard, we have no reservations whatsoever when it comes to engaging in that debate; we can face it with our heads held high.

Madam President, allow me first of all to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for the assistance in this report, which has made it significantly stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being observed, which should be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, a key factor in overcoming the crisis and achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism.
And trust, transparency—a fundamental principle of democracy and good governance—to which Commissioner Bernier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, complicates the adoption of a global legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability from a cross-sectional analysis that takes into account the diverse needs, capacities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of current deficiencies, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
It presents an ambitious proposal, but it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or of the options available, or of their lack of awareness of existing claims and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all of these reasons that, in order to address the deficiencies—that is, the problems—it is necessary to adopt a strategy of reinforcing vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures into their legislation to guarantee adequate protection.

It should go beyond mere information, particularly in those areas where a higher level of expertise is demonstrated and where the greatest number of consumer complaints are recorded. The financial sector, given its complexity, implies that any consumer potentially may be vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is requested to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, expanding on clear explanations and using straightforward language regarding the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector in relation to advertising.

Foods high in fats, salts, and sugars, and children and young people, who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods; the transportation sector, which continues to often face challenges when vulnerable individuals travel. The energy and telecommunications sector.

where a lack of transparency can, in some cases, create an additional difficulty for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, or in access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing the available mechanisms.

50 percent of the active population while many of them are already without any social coverage or unemployment benefits as this unfolds while we transition from a situation evolving from concerning to

from sustainable to unsustainable and even to the dramatic, the commission presents itself once more in this parliament, in this chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true government of the Union, which is what it is, and moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities; governing means setting priorities, it means taking the initiative, moreover, with the objective of achieving some end, some goal. And, furthermore, the Commission is not doing so.

Governing is not simply restructuring funds, nor even announcing such a restructuring to improve public perception, but rather elevating an ambitious, lasting, and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

Goar is not about resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate exceeding 20% and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the scale of the problem we face.

governs not to exceed before the pressures of the Board of Commissioners or other Member States of the Council that insist on attempting to convince us that we will only emerge from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, by renouncing salaries, labor rights, or compensation; that only a future of precariousness awaits us as a generation.

Because if this were true, furthermore, Commissioner, that we only achieve competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, and it is not.

Allocate funds to increase the budget. Utilize the European Social Fund as an instrument if necessary. Push to further modify this social support policy to benefit the countries that are struggling the most, and remember that behind each statistic lies a person experiencing hardship.

Generally, we are faced with a good G+ regulation necessary, specifically, in certain actions concerning the control of import norms for textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
However, we are concerned about the SPG’s exclusion, starting in 2014, from determining two countries classified as upper-middle income countries, such as countries in Latin America.
What about these middle-income countries with undiversified exports?
Why not introduce a diversification criterion into export strategy?
Because this could produce two speeds; countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador — would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we should support a period of transition, and that amendments will be presented with this transitional period to adapt to this situation for these countries and to provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they may benefit from it.

I already endorsed Mrs. Nadelcheva’s report, when I was able to accompany her on the Congo mission together with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I observed few communities with a more evident desire to establish and participate in democracy.
But a people to believe in democracy also need to believe in their State and their Government. And that will not be possible solely through electoral support or external support.
They also need a requirement to combat corruption and break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the world's resource-rich countries.

And it is necessary to decide and denounce that a portion of the violence they experience is imported, or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinational corporations that, from Europe or other continents or other states, are capable of participating in corruption, without regard for fostering struggles over those resources to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Mr. Ashtonnom, you understand the absolute nature of your competition when I say that a greater demand for traceability and transparency from multinational European corporations and others from other continents who collaborate there would be as beneficial for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at an electoral and technical level.

Madam President, since I entered this parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
It is that silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls worldwide suffer, seven million, I repeat, seven million.
An unbearable figure for anyone who pauses to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, or religious reasons—all of them false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced primarily on girls as young as two or even one year old, can lead to death by hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
It concerns us, esteemed members, of abuse, of cruelty, of torture against girls, and that degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To that end, we must activate all the preventative mechanisms available to our legal system and I encourage our judges to act to prevent female genital mutilation.
girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, that the law in Europe speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I urge civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still much road to travel, but many of us will not stop, because we owe it to the seven million women who have undergone mutilation.

The feeling of helplessness was of such magnitude that, by necessity, Europe had to react, and it has done so for the good of all. Because the great winner of this past Summit has been the euro.

Madam President, Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to highlight the significant work of Ms. Macagan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs in reaching this agreement.
Upon initial review, it was very important, as the regulations we had approved in 2010 were coming into effect and needed to be revised.
Not because the legislation itself was flawed—the legislation was very good—but as has been said, the recent events, known to all, demonstrated that there was a certain
A body of water that needed to be rectified to prevent recurrence, and specific points of medication surveillance and security, once marketed, required reinforcement.
Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, the holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw, request the withdrawal of, or suspend the authorization will
obligation to declare the real reasons and the motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of a drug's authorization.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all concerned countries and Member States where this medication is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without unduly burdening the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies.

The second significant modification achieved is that all authorized products subject to post-authorization safety studies will be automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Finally, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and therefore this Plenary Session must approve this proposal.

Mr. President, I want to once again thank everyone who has made this Directive a reality: to the Secretariat, to the Commissioner, to the rapporteur, to all those I have forgotten, and to all my colleagues who have stood with us.
I want to say to the victims, to all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinctions, that for us, they and their families have faces, have names, are real, and precisely in their name.

We will work to ensure that this Directive does not remain merely a paper exercise, but that, with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, it has a rapid and effective implementation, which is what we all expect and all
citizen.

I believe there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and continue to want a dedicated Directive. But I will tell you that the Directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victims and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am certain that this is a first and important step that will be followed by many others, opening those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When asked in my country what I do in Europe, I will be able to say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me a great deal of strength to continue working.

I am certain that, with the support and commitment, not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will, together and also with that of the Honorable Member, bring the victims out of that unjust oblivion.

Mr. President, my colleague Turmes has done admirable work because pushing forward a regulation like this required the courage of this rapporteur, who has skillfully neutralized many and cleverly positioned obstacles.
It has been worth it, because energy efficiency and its savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should commend significant measures such as the requirement for the renovation of public buildings, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private enterprises.
However, the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs will be of no avail if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives on the part of the regions, the municipalities, and European citizens.
I wish to highlight the participation of these latter.
For the time being, what is observed is a great deal of frivolity among authorities and among citizens.
Citizens. Don’t we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter people seated on heated street terraces?
Mr. Friend Turnnes, we must not spare any effort to save energy.
One must commend speaker Irache García for the work she has done and congratulate herself on the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is regrettable that the council cannot join us tonight.
The new quality scheme for agricultural products represents a simplification of the system and an acceleration of existing authorization procedures—and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a significant achievement that the obligation to use the community logo has been included for protected designations of origin and geographical indications, as this allows for improved visibility of European productions.
It seems to me that it is noteworthy to reinforce the provisions for the protection of quality appeals in bilateral agreements with third countries and to establish a legal basis for
to defend the logo of the European Union in those third countries, because I genuinely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be an unrenounceable objective.
I regret that this package has been somewhat diminished during the negotiation, and it is a shame that the Council is not here to hear it, because the original quality package that it proposed…
The Commission has somewhat overlooked the commercial standards and supply management by quality designation of origin bodies, detached from the agreement and, as I say, leaving it a little hollow.
I believe it is necessary to address the obstinacy demonstrated by the Council in these two matters, refusing to heed the Parliament's reasonable positions.
The management of supply by the appellations of origin should have been defended and was indeed defended within the CAP.

Mr. President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia, and Peru is an important agreement, and the safeguard clause—with the amendments we have presented—aims to be straightforward, efficient, and to provide assurances.

We have introduced amendments to protect European production in accordance with the Treaties and establish security mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the Agreement is established.
Protection of ultraperipheral zones is necessary because they are not diversified by economic factors, as this impacts a large number.
creates more than ten thousand direct and indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely affected by unemployment and its particular circumstances.
For example, Canarian cheese exhibits great specificity in agriculture, culture, and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary where we are going to establish the agreement in Central America, Colombia, and Peru, because trade is fundamental for development, and development entails labor rights, sustainability, and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the speaker’s work is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say, within this framework, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can observe.
We forget what Puffendorf already taught: that general laws should be few in number and their meaning must be understood correctly.
For them, those who promulgate it, must employ all possible clarity.
And Montesquieu consistently insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is to say, we must avoid esoteric jargon, replete with neologisms and unwarranted linguistic borrowings, because it generates a pernicious web where traps lurk and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even professionals of the Right—judges, lawyers—to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way of demonstrating his respect for the citizen.
Representative, I have just spent the scant time I had insulting and denigrating from a position of utter ignorance.
Ignorance—you know the Spanish Constitution.

Because what the Vice President, Mr. Vidalcudraras, has stated is nothing more nor less than the application of what is stipulated in the Spanish Constitution. Everything else are singular, personal assessments that are absolutely irrelevant and which I can respect, but I disregard.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, there exists an old principle that has passed from the legal realm to the political one, namely, *pacta sunt servanda*, that is to say, agreements are to be kept.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Following the adoption of these agreements, market pressure eased, and they welcomed decisions that could break the vicious cycle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move forward toward a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irrevocably.
The European Council observed last week contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions regarding progress towards a banking union are satisfactory.

It is also positive the agreement regarding the launch of the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate that the responsibility for launching it be entrusted to the Ministers of Economy of Luozona.
But he will be permitted to make a critical assessment of the biased interpretations that have been made of it, in a unilateral manner.

It is not permissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that may distort the mandate granted to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we applaud the recounting of matters as agreements when they were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move toward a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
It is also necessary to establish a common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are undeniable: increased competition, an expansion of the product offering, and.
services, the creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers, and greater protection—still not enough, and we cannot afford complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist, and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully exploiting the advantages of the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and bolster citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as acknowledged by the Commission in its communication last week.

Esteemed Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis compels us to be ambitious, to go much further, and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment, and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
President, I too would like to congratulate the speaker and the rest of the colleagues who have worked on this reform very adequately.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and obscure financial instruments that are linked to derivative instruments and to transactions outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns at great speed.
It is necessary to bring financial operations into a transparent market to guarantee the proper formation of prices and the competitiveness of negotiable products.
But, above all, it is essential that the information provided be comprehensible to investors who must have full knowledge to freely consent to the risks they assume.
It is of no use to have transparency as a brilliant flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
I appreciate Mrs. Thssen's report, because I believe that anything that reinforces the role and authority of this Parliament in political debate is moving in the right direction.
Far too often, we hear the accusation leveled against European institutions for their limited democratic quality.
This is a statement made lightly, which is not the occasion for entering into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament possesses the same legitimacy as any national Parliament and is, indeed, likely to be governed by more transparent rules than some, and furthermore, to allow greater freedom to its members.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass the filter represented by this Parliament before their definitive approval and subsequently, upon examining their execution and results.
