The mechanism of stability must appear before this assembly so that the deputies can have access to exhaustive information and firsthand information.
Mr. President, 5.3% of the active population works in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, coupled with business strategy, generally leads to outsourcing and corporate restructuring.
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting ten assembly plants and potentially a thousand workers.

Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term perspective prevails, in which the primary element is achieving competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must say that on the very day Ford communicated the suspension of the Gen plant, the Ford company in Valencia was also informed, in the same corporate communication, that its production would be transferred to Germany.

Therefore, for this reason, we believe it is a general problem of Europe. We believe that the creation of a legal framework at the European level is essential, one that anticipates changes and underscores the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common policy on security and defence.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a distinct European dimension, in contrast to the minority and Eurosceptic factions that also prevail in this Chamber.
Mr. Danjián's report, for which I wish to express my gratitude for his spirit of consensus-building throughout its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Social Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European Defence Strategy.
We have also noted that a strong common policy on security and defense is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is acquiring significant dimensions for our global security.
It concerns cybersecurity and cyber defense, reports that we are also debating today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis in which Member States are being compelled to cut their defense budgets, it is precisely when such European projects are most needed.
Therefore, it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being strongly challenged today.
I conclude by affirming that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with President Vor Rapuy’s project for the December 2013 Council.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and the Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Having accepted the legitimacy of both positions beforehand, achieving a balance is unavoidable.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that, in our judgment, the Presidency’s proposal is unacceptable.
A reduction of 75 billion euros on the already inevitably meager proposal from the European Commission is sterile and futile.
And it’s not just that; the new cuts directly to agricultural and cohesion policies represent crossing the red line that Spain established from the outset of the negotiations.
Esteemed Sir, the time for debating a purported dichotomy between authority and growth has passed.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
With this budget, one reaches nowhere. Rather, it constitutes a missile in the waterline.
Your Excellency, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with significantly fewer resources, and especially if what is available is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply means the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any trace of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, to whom we owe thanks for their dedication in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for the Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful declaration of interpretation of the Treaties just the other day in Cádiz, for a supposed maximalist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as Guarantor of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent State, it shall be considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this may be recorded and that this certain and consistent doctrine of the Commission may continue to remain vital for the assurance of all.
